BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 24, 1921

J. H. U. AND SWATHMORE DIVIDE HONORS
‘CLEVER FIELDING AND HITTING FEATURE SWARTHMORE VICTORY
Hopkins Nine Outclassed by Visitors in
9-to-6 Game. Grace Stars Again
in Field. Reifschneider
Hits Homer.

(

Swarthmore College broke into
the midst of Johns- Hopkins winning streak last Saturday at Homewood, and by consistent hitting and
smart fielding left the diamond a
victor by a 9 to 6 score.
"Andy" Knecht, .tossing them
over for the Black and Blue, was
less effective than usual, allowing
twelve hits and passing two men.
The home team, on the other hand,
was able to connect safely with but
six_ of Clancy's shoots, two of
which, on a two-bagger, were collected by Heuyter.
"Buck" Grace once again furnished the fielding feature of the
game when, in the final inning, he
ran out into right field and, with
one hand, captured a Texas leaguer
which seemed destined to be a sure
safety. This catch and Reifschneider's homer, with two men
on, accounting for three of Hopkins' runs, constituted the most
thrilling incidents of a fast contest
replete with long hits and clever
fielding.
The second inning proved to be
the home team's Waterloo. After
two men were out in this stanza,
the visitor came back and four
clean hits, combined with loose fielding, netted them five runs.
Hopkins put over its first two
runs in the third, when, after Sharretts had fanned, Keen received a
base on balls, went to third on
Knecht's hit to right, and scored
while Rich was beating out a roller
down to first . "Andy" counted a
moment later after Yarnall had
caught "Bill" Wood's fly in right
Three more came across in the fifth
as a result of "Reify's" four-ply
swat, and Hopkins' final tally came
in the eighth, when, after reaching
first on an error, stealing second
and going to third on Keen's fly,
Sharretts crossed the plate on Rich's
single to right
Knecht tightened up after the
visitors had pushed over two men
in the fifth and thereafter allowed
but three safeties.

PLAY NIGHT TO BE GIVEN

ANNUAL R. 0. T. C. INSPEC-

IN BARN ON FRIDAY

TION HELD THURSDAY

Dramatic Club to Present Two One-act
Plays. Both Written by Club Members. Banquet and Elections to Follow Show.

AND FRIDAY

Though for a time it had been
planned to give two playlets after
the interfraternity banquet last Friday night, it was found necessary
to postpone their production a week
so that now they will be put on in
the studio in the Barn, Friday evening, May 27th, at eight o'clock.
The program will consist of "The
Return," a romance by E. S. Basford, '21, and "Caveman Courtship," a burlesque, by Joseph A.
Moran, '23. The first is being
coached by Brawner, West and Basford; the second by the author himself. By Friday the playlets will
be worked into fine shape and will
run with unusual smoothness and
ease.
The casts are as follows:
"THE RETURN"
By E. S. Basford.
Henry D. West,'23
Morris Keen, '22
P. B. Stevens,'22, Christian
E. F. Buchner, Jr., '22,
Myra

Sidney
Annie
Gilford
Gilford

"CAVEMAN COURTSHIP"
By Joseph A. Moran.
J. A. Moran, '23
Betty
Isaac Hamburger, 24,
The Caveman
J D. Kerwin, '23
The,Tramp
It has been the purpose of the
club in these "play-nights" in the
Barn to produce playlets written by
members and acted by undergraduates who are trying out for places
in the cast of the main productions.
Through these new talent is developed and given a training in dramatics which would be impossible
through any other means. As there
will be no charge for admission on
Friday night, it is hoped that a
great number of undergraduates
will be present.
The banquet and election of officers for next year will be held on
Friday after the plays. Attendance
will be limited to members of the
club and invited guests.

Staff Officers from Washington View
Battalion on Field and in Classrooms. Inspectors Well
Pleased With Unit.

After many false alarms the belated annual inspection of the R. 0.
T. C. finally took place last Thursday and Friday. The ideal weather
drew quite a large crowd and the
music furnished by a band from
Camp Holabird kept everyone in
good spirits. The inspecting officers were: Colonel E. J. Williams,
General Staff Corps; LieutenantColonel W. R. Gibson, Major General Adelbert Cronkhite and Major
Earl H. Metzger.
The first event on the program
was a review, followed by battalion
inspection. The manual of arms
and physical drill were performed
with perfection and the latter especially made a big hit with the inspectors. The battalion drilled as
a company for a few minutes under
Cadet Major Chisholm and then the
companies were turned over to
their commanders for close and extended order drill. After the drill
the students broke up into specialties and the inspectors made a rapid
tour, taking in the signal squad,
model bridge construction, indoor
and outdoor gallery fire and the
work on automatic rifles, machine
guns and one-pounders.
Company C undertook a difficult
field problem and made a great success of it. Lake Montebello was the
scene of the operations and the company made a successful attack upon
the "enemy's" outpost line. On Friday the recitation classes in theoretical instruction were heard by the
visitors. The behavior of the unit
during the inspection was all that
could be asked, the drill was scrappy and little, if anything, was
"balled up." President Goodnow
and Dean Latane accompanied the
officers during the inspection. On
Thursday evening the visitors were
tendered a dinner at the Johns Hopkins Club.

LACROSSE VICTORY EVENS
UP DAY FOR JOHNS HOPKINS
Swarthmore Stickmen Unable to Follow
Example of Ball Team. Both Teams
Show Poor Stickwork. Defense Plays Steady Game.

With both teams showing poor
stickwork, but fighting hard at all
times, Hopkins defeated Swarthmore in lacrosse at Homewood
Field Saturday, 6 to 4. Things
were evenly matched throughout
the whole game and Swarthmore
gave the Black and Blue a hard
fight at all times.
During the first fifteen minutes
neither team scored, inability to
hold the ball in front of goal after
it had been worked down the field
marring many plays. Swarthmore
made the first goal of the day when
Geiger got the ball far mit from the
goal and on a long shot got it past
Benedict. Hopkins came right
back, however, when Dick Holmes
caught the ball in front of goad and
with a hard shot put it into he net.
From then on the ball was always
around the Swarthmore goal, Burnham and Stuart counting for two
more goals. Swarthmore then
braced and made two goals, one of
them being a short shot by Buckma, and the other a hard shot
through a scrimmage in front of
goal by Katzenbach.. Coach Knipp
then showed good headwork by substituting Bauernschmidt, who quickly made a goal after receiving a
short pass from Griffin, making the
score 4 to 3.
The second half opened without
any scoring, until Buckman made
his second goal, after pretty teamwork between himself and Geiger.
This tied the score and the Hopkins stand all calling for a score.
They were soon satisfied, when Zoller, getting the ball in front of Hopkins' goal, passed to Parsons, who

FINAL COTILLION GIVEN

BALL TEAM CONTINUES WIN-

LAST WEEK

NING STREAK

Dancing Contest Features Third Dance
of the Year. C. E. Hall Attractively Decorated.

Downs Gallaudet in Slow Game by 9to-0 Score. Tucker Allows But
Five Bingles. Strouse Stars
in the Field.

The final cotillion, the third given
this year by the Cotillion Board, of
which Vernon E. Stuart (otherwise
known as "Shorty") is president,
was held on Monday of last week
and was fully the success that- it
was expected to be.
The chaperons in attendance
were: Dr. and Mrs. John H. La
tine, Dr. and Mrs. John B. Whitehead, Dr. and Mrs. Ronald T. Abercrombie, Dr. and Mrs. David M.
Robinson. The Cotillion Club consists of the following members:
Vernon E. Stuart, president; Norman C. Keyes, secretary-treasurer;
Clinton C. Waters, Christopher
Johnston, Frederick W. Lipps, Elmer J. Jones, Jr., Richard T. Earle,
David D. Thomas and Holmes
Boyd.
After the fourteenth dance on the
program, five of the young ladies
present engaged in a contest to determine the best dancer in attendance, and -Miss Elizabeth Vickers
was awarded the decision by the
judges. All the competitors were
pr esented bouquets.
The Cotillion was held, as were
the previous ones, in the Civil Engineering Hall and the music was
furnished by Bob Iula's orchestra.
The blackboard was covered with
zi striking design in the form of an
enormous H, set against a background of diagonal Black and Blue.
The closing hour, one o'clock,
ended the dancing entirely too soon
for those participating, but next
year is not so very far off and more
enjoyable occasions than even
those just passed may be awaited.

The Johns Hopkins baseball team
continued its winning streak by
taking the measure of the Gallaudet
ball tossers to the tune of 9-0, in a
rather slow game at Homewood last
Wednesday.
Bill Tucker, who served up the
shoots for the local artists, was in
rare form, allowing but five scattered singles from his delivery, and
retiring nine batters by the strikeout route. He forced most of his
• opponents to send up weak flies,
which were easily gathered in by
his teammates, as is evidenced by
the fact that only five assists were
registered by the Black and Blue.
Johns Hopkins took the lead in
the second inning, and her supremacy thereafter was never questioned. In the fifth and eighth innings only did the visitors threaten
to score, men reaching third in each
of these stanzas, but Tucker tightened up and had no difficulty in
retiring the remainder of the side.
In the second round Sharretts
lead off with a Texas leaguer to left
center, and Keen beat out a bunt
down the third base line. Andy
Knecht fouled out, but Bill Wood
connected with the first ball pitched
to him for a slashing single to right,
scoring Sharretts. Strouse grounded to shortstop, who threw Keen
out at third. Tucker then lifted a
high fly just over third base, which
La Fountain juggled about and finalijr dropped, allowing both Wood
and Strouse to tally. Grace fanned,
retiring the side.
In the fourth, off two errors and
passed ball one more counter was
rung up. The seventh brought two

WENSEL TO ADDRESS SCIENTIFIC CLUB
Will Speak Next Wednesday on "Structure of the Atom." Is Member
of Physics Department.

The "Scientific Club" will be addressed Wednesday at 4:15, in the
M. E. lecture room, on "The Structure of the Atom," by Mr. H. L.
Wensel. The public is invited to
attend.
The speaker will touch upon the
subjects of radioactivity and atomic
energy. Mr. Wensel will also discuss in some detail the remarkable
achievement of Professor Rutherford in transmitting one element
into another, and the enormous
store of energy in atoms as a possible supply of energy for the future race.
Mr. Wensel was at the Washing-ton University when he, in common
with other scientists, were called
to Washington for service in the
Bureau of Standards during the
war. After spending three years
in the department of optical instruments he came to Hopkins. For the
past two years he has been a member of the Physic Department of
this University.

KOLLEGIATE
KLIPPINGS

By winning all their matches,
'Washington and Lee 'tennis team
defeated the University of Maryland by a score of 6 to 0. Buieh,
Snively and Mason represented
Washington and Lee.
The male students of Cornell are
taking their stand against co-education. They recommend permanent restriction on the number of
women students and complete segregation as the ultimate end.
Amherst's faculty has declared
twenty-five of her varsity baseball
players ineligible. The coaches are
having a strenuous time piecing together a new team.
There is a possibility that Cornell, Dartmouth, Columbia and
Pennsylvania may combine to form
a "big four" destined to rival the
"big three," Yale, Harvard and
Princeton, in the intercollegiate
world.

NEW ARTS AND SCIENCES
CATALOGUE DISTRIBUTED

MUSICAL CLUB ELECTS WALDO HAMBLETON PRESIDENT

Differs But Little from That of Last
Year. 393 Undergraduates Enrolled in Academic Department.

Eight Members Awarded Varsity Seals.
"Ed" Spieker Receives Honorary
Seal As Mark of Appreciation.

The new catalogue of the College
of Arts and Sciences differs but
little from its predecessor. There
have been several changes in the
personnel of the Faculty and in the
courses to be given during the corning year, however, that might be
worth noting.
The Board of Collegiate Studies
has several new members: Major
E. B. Garey, commandant of the
R. 0. T. C.; W. B. Kouwenhoven,
J. C. Smallwood, G. H. Cartledge,
T. L. McMurray, J. R. Musselman
and Broadus Mitchell. The several
committees of the board remain unchanged. The name of Ryland N.
Dempster appears as assistant registrar. The members of the board
of last year whose names do not appear on this year's list are: Henry
Wood, 0. O. Ellis and C. C.
Thomas.

Waldo Hambleton was elected to
succeed "Doug" Coulter as president of the Hopkins Combined Musical Clubs at the meeting of the
clubs on Friday, May 20. Other officers elected for next year were:
Hugh Smallwood, business manager, and Bernard Kuder, treasurer.
With these men at the head of the
musical clubs hope to have a most
successful season next year.
The Musical Clubs wish to announce the awarding of varsity seals
to the following members: Bowers,
Hambleton, Scheridt, Vanneman,
Parsons, Kuder, Collins and Jacobson. An honorary seal has been
awarded to "Ed" Speiker to express
the appreciation of the entire club
for his valuable services and esteemed leadership.
The clubs will give their last concert this season at Lehman's Hall,
on Monday, May 30.

To'go a little further and in a
slightly different strain, however,
we believe it not out of place to
here reiterate the oft-repeated and
well-founded statement to the effct that the really successful man
is one who does well all that he
does at all. . We feel that this applies to the college man as much
as to his elder brother in some
other line of endeavor. Studies
come with a surprising degree of
ease to some of us, while others are
more proficient in athletic or other
lines of activity; but can any of us
feel that we are making a true success of our college days unless we
"make a go" of both,lines?
Theodore Roosevelt, whom many
of us consider to have been America's greatest and truest American
of all times, was ,when a young
wan, we remember, inclined to be
more or less weak and fragile. Perseverance and determination combined with tireless training, however, made of him that living dynamo of energy which is remembered,
respected and revered by one and
all.
But few of us, if any, ever dream,
of course, of following in the footsteps of this illustrious man, but
can we not all become more of a
credit at least to ourselves and to
our Alma M.ater by doing our "best
bit," both in classroom and on the
campus?

SPEAKING OF EXAMS—

The Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir: It hardly seems necessary to emphasize the necessity of
passing the final examinations
Which are so near at hand. Each
man knows that for his own benefit he must get through them to the
best of his ability and finish this
rather trying year with results that
will show his best efforts. The
athletic teams and other undergraduate organizations were greatly
hampered because much of their
best material fell down in the midyears and became "black-listed,"
even in face of the lowering of the
requirements by the faculty. Every
man owes it first to himself to pass
and pass high, then to the teams,
clubs and societies of which he is
a member, so that they may contain
the best red-blooded Hopkins—enthusiastic men who are here.
Heaven only knows there is a deplorably small percentage of undergraduates at Hopkins who participate in its non-curriculum activities
and to have a part of this blacklisted means that Hopkins cannot
put forth its best. Many of us are
accustomed to putting off the final
studying until the last minute—a
practice which is never the best in
the long run. Hard as it may be to
give up such interesting "classes"
as Barn 3 and 4, yet the time devoted to them could well be spent
now in reviewing those "good old
notes" and text books. Let's hope.
that no true Hopkins man will be
black-listed.
F. R. S.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 24, 1921

S
TENNIS TEAM LOSES TO
DELAWARE

Porm

Duffy Injured But Continues to Play.
Pickford Only Winner.

The Johns Hopkins tennis team
lost its second start of the season
last Saturday against Delaware College, at Delaware, four matches to
two. Captain Duffy, of the visiting team, fell and injured his ,thumb
in the first match, but pluckily con'.
tinued, although in great pain.
Pickford was the only Hopkins
player to remain undefeated, winning his singles match, 6-3 and 6-2,
and, paired with Wells in the doubles, came out ahead by the same
score.
As is shown by the fact that two
of the matches went into an extra
set, the competition was quite close
at all times, particularly-in the Challenger-Wells meeting in which the
former won but one more game

J. H. U. AND SWATHMORE DIVIDE HONORS
‘CLEVER FIELDING AND HITTING FEATURE SWARTHMORE VICTORY
Hopkins Nine Outclassed by Visitors in
9-to-6 Game. Grace Stars Again
in Field. Reifschneider
Hits Homer.

(

Swarthmore College broke into
the midst of Johns- Hopkins winning streak last Saturday at Homewood, and by consistent hitting and
smart fielding left the diamond a
victor by a 9 to 6 score.
"Andy" Knecht, .tossing them
over for the Black and Blue, was
less effective than usual, allowing
twelve hits and passing two men.
The home team, on the other hand,
was able to connect safely with but
six_ of Clancy's shoots, two of
which, on a two-bagger, were collected by Heuyter.
"Buck" Grace once again furnished the fielding feature of the
game when, in the final inning, he
ran out into right field and, with
one hand, captured a Texas leaguer
which seemed destined to be a sure
safety. This catch and Reifschneider's homer, with two men
on, accounting for three of Hopkins' runs, constituted the most
thrilling incidents of a fast contest
replete with long hits and clever
fielding.
The second inning proved to be
the home team's Waterloo. After
two men were out in this stanza,
the visitor came back and four
clean hits, combined with loose fielding, netted them five runs.
Hopkins put over its first two
runs in the third, when, after Sharretts had fanned, Keen received a
base on balls, went to third on
Knecht's hit to right, and scored
while Rich was beating out a roller
down to first . "Andy" counted a
moment later after Yarnall had
caught "Bill" Wood's fly in right
Three more came across in the fifth
as a result of "Reify's" four-ply
swat, and Hopkins' final tally came
in the eighth, when, after reaching
first on an error, stealing second
and going to third on Keen's fly,
Sharretts crossed the plate on Rich's
single to right
Knecht tightened up after the
visitors had pushed over two men
in the fifth and thereafter allowed
but three safeties.

PLAY NIGHT TO BE GIVEN

ANNUAL R. 0. T. C. INSPEC-

IN BARN ON FRIDAY

TION HELD THURSDAY

Dramatic Club to Present Two One-act
Plays. Both Written by Club Members. Banquet and Elections to Follow Show.

AND FRIDAY

Though for a time it had been
planned to give two playlets after
the interfraternity banquet last Friday night, it was found necessary
to postpone their production a week
so that now they will be put on in
the studio in the Barn, Friday evening, May 27th, at eight o'clock.
The program will consist of "The
Return," a romance by E. S. Basford, '21, and "Caveman Courtship," a burlesque, by Joseph A.
Moran, '23. The first is being
coached by Brawner, West and Basford; the second by the author himself. By Friday the playlets will
be worked into fine shape and will
run with unusual smoothness and
ease.
The casts are as follows:
"THE RETURN"
By E. S. Basford.
Henry D. West,'23
Morris Keen, '22
P. B. Stevens,'22, Christian
E. F. Buchner, Jr., '22,
Myra

Sidney
Annie
Gilford
Gilford

"CAVEMAN COURTSHIP"
By Joseph A. Moran.
J. A. Moran, '23
Betty
Isaac Hamburger, 24,
The Caveman
J D. Kerwin, '23
The,Tramp
It has been the purpose of the
club in these "play-nights" in the
Barn to produce playlets written by
members and acted by undergraduates who are trying out for places
in the cast of the main productions.
Through these new talent is developed and given a training in dramatics which would be impossible
through any other means. As there
will be no charge for admission on
Friday night, it is hoped that a
great number of undergraduates
will be present.
The banquet and election of officers for next year will be held on
Friday after the plays. Attendance
will be limited to members of the
club and invited guests.

Staff Officers from Washington View
Battalion on Field and in Classrooms. Inspectors Well
Pleased With Unit.

After many false alarms the belated annual inspection of the R. 0.
T. C. finally took place last Thursday and Friday. The ideal weather
drew quite a large crowd and the
music furnished by a band from
Camp Holabird kept everyone in
good spirits. The inspecting officers were: Colonel E. J. Williams,
General Staff Corps; LieutenantColonel W. R. Gibson, Major General Adelbert Cronkhite and Major
Earl H. Metzger.
The first event on the program
was a review, followed by battalion
inspection. The manual of arms
and physical drill were performed
with perfection and the latter especially made a big hit with the inspectors. The battalion drilled as
a company for a few minutes under
Cadet Major Chisholm and then the
companies were turned over to
their commanders for close and extended order drill. After the drill
the students broke up into specialties and the inspectors made a rapid
tour, taking in the signal squad,
model bridge construction, indoor
and outdoor gallery fire and the
work on automatic rifles, machine
guns and one-pounders.
Company C undertook a difficult
field problem and made a great success of it. Lake Montebello was the
scene of the operations and the company made a successful attack upon
the "enemy's" outpost line. On Friday the recitation classes in theoretical instruction were heard by the
visitors. The behavior of the unit
during the inspection was all that
could be asked, the drill was scrappy and little, if anything, was
"balled up." President Goodnow
and Dean Latane accompanied the
officers during the inspection. On
Thursday evening the visitors were
tendered a dinner at the Johns Hopkins Club.

LACROSSE VICTORY EVENS
UP DAY FOR JOHNS HOPKINS
Swarthmore Stickmen Unable to Follow
Example of Ball Team. Both Teams
Show Poor Stickwork. Defense Plays Steady Game.

With both teams showing poor
stickwork, but fighting hard at all
times, Hopkins defeated Swarthmore in lacrosse at Homewood
Field Saturday, 6 to 4. Things
were evenly matched throughout
the whole game and Swarthmore
gave the Black and Blue a hard
fight at all times.
During the first fifteen minutes
neither team scored, inability to
hold the ball in front of goal after
it had been worked down the field
marring many plays. Swarthmore
made the first goal of the day when
Geiger got the ball far mit from the
goal and on a long shot got it past
Benedict. Hopkins came right
back, however, when Dick Holmes
caught the ball in front of goad and
with a hard shot put it into he net.
From then on the ball was always
around the Swarthmore goal, Burnham and Stuart counting for two
more goals. Swarthmore then
braced and made two goals, one of
them being a short shot by Buckma, and the other a hard shot
through a scrimmage in front of
goal by Katzenbach.. Coach Knipp
then showed good headwork by substituting Bauernschmidt, who quickly made a goal after receiving a
short pass from Griffin, making the
score 4 to 3.
The second half opened without
any scoring, until Buckman made
his second goal, after pretty teamwork between himself and Geiger.
This tied the score and the Hopkins stand all calling for a score.

BALL TEAM CONTINUES WIN-

NING STREAK

Dancing Contest Features Third Dance
of the Year. C. E. Hall Attractively Decorated.

Downs Gallaudet in Slow Game by 9to-0 Score. Tucker Allows But
Five Bingles. Strouse Stars
in the Field.

The final cotillion, the third given
this year by the Cotillion Board, of
which Vernon E. Stuart (otherwise
known as "Shorty") is president,
was held on Monday of last week
and was fully the success that- it
was expected to be.
The chaperons in attendance
were: Dr. and Mrs. John H. La
tine, Dr. and Mrs. John B. Whitehead, Dr. and Mrs. Ronald T. Abercrombie, Dr. and Mrs. David M.
Robinson. The Cotillion Club consists of the following members:
Vernon E. Stuart, president; Norman C. Keyes, secretary-treasurer;
Clinton C. Waters, Christopher
Johnston, Frederick W. Lipps, Elmer J. Jones, Jr., Richard T. Earle,
David D. Thomas and Holmes
Boyd.
After the fourteenth dance on the
program, five of the young ladies
present engaged in a contest to determine the best dancer in attendance, and -Miss Elizabeth Vickers
was awarded the decision by the
judges. All the competitors were
pr esented bouquets.
The Cotillion was held, as were
the previous ones, in the Civil Engineering Hall and the music was
furnished by Bob Iula's orchestra.
The blackboard was covered with
zi striking design in the form of an
enormous H, set against a background of diagonal Black and Blue.
The closing hour, one o'clock,
ended the dancing entirely too soon
for those participating, but next
year is not so very far off and more
enjoyable occasions than even
those just passed may be awaited.

The Johns Hopkins baseball team
continued its winning streak by
taking the measure of the Gallaudet
ball tossers to the tune of 9-0, in a
rather slow game at Homewood last
Wednesday.
Bill Tucker, who served up the
shoots for the local artists, was in
rare form, allowing but five scattered singles from his delivery, and
retiring nine batters by the strikeout route. He forced most of his
• opponents to send up weak flies,
which were easily gathered in by
his teammates, as is evidenced by
the fact that only five assists were
registered by the Black and Blue.
Johns Hopkins took the lead in
the second inning, and her supremacy thereafter was never questioned. In the fifth and eighth innings only did the visitors threaten
to score, men reaching third in each
of these stanzas, but Tucker tightened up and had no difficulty in
retiring the remainder of the side.
In the second round Sharretts
lead off with a Texas leaguer to left
center, and Keen beat out a bunt
down the third base line. Andy
Knecht fouled out, but Bill Wood
connected with the first ball pitched
to him for a slashing single to right,
scoring Sharretts. Strouse grounded to shortstop, who threw Keen
out at third. Tucker then lifted a
high fly just over third base, which
La Fountain juggled about and finalijr dropped, allowing both Wood
and Strouse to tally. Grace fanned,
retiring the side.
In the fourth, off two errors and
passed ball one more counter was
rung up. The seventh brought two

WENSEL TO ADDRESS SCIENTIFIC CLUB
Will Speak Next Wednesday on "Structure of the Atom." Is Member
of Physics Department.

The "Scientific Club" will be addressed Wednesday at 4:15, in the
M. E. lecture room, on "The Structure of the Atom," by Mr. H. L.
Wensel. The public is invited to
attend.
The speaker will touch upon the
subjects of radioactivity and atomic
energy. Mr. Wensel will also discuss in some detail the remarkable
achievement of Professor Rutherford in transmitting one element
into another, and the enormous
store of energy in atoms as a possible supply of energy for the future race.
Mr. Wensel was at the Washing-ton University when he, in common
with other scientists, were called
to Washington for service in the
Bureau of Standards during the
war. After spending three years
in the department of optical instruments he came to Hopkins. For the
past two years he has been a member of the Physic Department of
this University.

By winning all their matches,
'Washington and Lee 'tennis team
defeated the University of Maryland by a score of 6 to 0. Buieh,
Snively and Mason represented
Washington and Lee.
The male students of Cornell are
taking their stand against co-education. They recommend permanent restriction on the number of
women students and complete segregation as the ultimate end.
Amherst's faculty has declared
twenty-five of her varsity baseball
players ineligible. The coaches are
having a strenuous time piecing together a new team.
There is a possibility that Cornell, Dartmouth, Columbia and
Pennsylvania may combine to form
a "big four" destined to rival the
"big three," Yale, Harvard and
Princeton, in the intercollegiate

NEW ARTS AND SCIENCES
CATALOGUE DISTRIBUTED

MUSICAL CLUB ELECTS WALDO HAMBLETON PRESIDENT

Differs But Little from That of Last
Year. 393 Undergraduates Enrolled in Academic Department.

Eight Members Awarded Varsity Seals.
"Ed" Spieker Receives Honorary
Seal As Mark of Appreciation.

The new catalogue of the College
of Arts and Sciences differs but
little from its predecessor. There
have been several changes in the
personnel of the Faculty and in the
courses to be given during the corning year, however, that might be
worth noting.
The Board of Collegiate Studies
has several new members: Major
E. B. Garey, commandant of the
R. 0. T. C.; W. B. Kouwenhoven,
J. C. Smallwood, G. H. Cartledge,
T. L. McMurray, J. R. Musselman
and Broadus Mitchell. The several
committees of the board remain unchanged. The name of Ryland N.
Dempster appears as assistant registrar. The members of the board
of last year whose names do not appear on this year's list are: Henry
Wood, 0. O. Ellis and C. C.
Thomas.

Waldo Hambleton was elected to
succeed "Doug" Coulter as president of the Hopkins Combined Musical Clubs at the meeting of the
clubs on Friday, May 20. Other officers elected for next year were:
Hugh Smallwood, business manager, and Bernard Kuder, treasurer.
With these men at the head of the
musical clubs hope to have a most
successful season next year.
The Musical Clubs wish to announce the awarding of varsity seals
to the following members: Bowers,
Hambleton, Scheridt, Vanneman,
Parsons, Kuder, Collins and Jacobson. An honorary seal has been
awarded to "Ed" Speiker to express
the appreciation of the entire club
for his valuable services and esteemed leadership.
The clubs will give their last concert this season at Lehman's Hall,
on Monday, May 30.

To'go a little further and in a
slightly different strain, however,
we believe it not out of place to
here reiterate the oft-repeated and
well-founded statement to the effct that the really successful man
is one who does well all that he
does at all. . We feel that this applies to the college man as much
as to his elder brother in some
other line of endeavor. Studies
come with a surprising degree of
ease to some of us, while others are
more proficient in athletic or other
lines of activity; but can any of us
feel that we are making a true success of our college days unless we
"make a go" of both,lines?
Theodore Roosevelt, whom many
of us consider to have been America's greatest and truest American
of all times, was ,when a young
wan, we remember, inclined to be
more or less weak and fragile. Perseverance and determination combined with tireless training, however, made of him that living dynamo of energy which is remembered,
respected and revered by one and
all.
But few of us, if any, ever dream,
of course, of following in the footsteps of this illustrious man, but
can we not all become more of a
credit at least to ourselves and to
our Alma M.ater by doing our "best
bit," both in classroom and on the
campus?

SPEAKING OF EXAMS—

The Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir: It hardly seems necessary to emphasize the necessity of
passing the final examinations
Which are so near at hand. Each
man knows that for his own benefit he must get through them to the
best of his ability and finish this
rather trying year with results that
will show his best efforts. The
athletic teams and other undergraduate organizations were greatly
hampered because much of their
best material fell down in the midyears and became "black-listed,"
even in face of the lowering of the
requirements by the faculty. Every
man owes it first to himself to pass
and pass high, then to the teams,
clubs and societies of which he is
a member, so that they may contain
the best red-blooded Hopkins—enthusiastic men who are here.
Heaven only knows there is a deplorably small percentage of undergraduates at Hopkins who participate in its non-curriculum activities
and to have a part of this blacklisted means that Hopkins cannot
put forth its best. Many of us are
accustomed to putting off the final
studying until the last minute—a
practice which is never the best in
the long run. Hard as it may be to
give up such interesting "classes"
as Barn 3 and 4, yet the time devoted to them could well be spent
now in reviewing those "good old
notes" and text books. Let's hope.
that no true Hopkins man will be
black-listed.
F. R. S.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 24, 1921

S
TENNIS TEAM LOSES TO
DELAWARE

Porm

Duffy Injured But Continues to Play.
Pickford Only Winner.

The Johns Hopkins tennis team
lost its second start of the season
last Saturday against Delaware College, at Delaware, four matches to
two. Captain Duffy, of the visiting team, fell and injured his ,thumb
in the first match, but pluckily con'.
tinued, although in great pain.
Pickford was the only Hopkins
player to remain undefeated, winning his singles match, 6-3 and 6-2,
and, paired with Wells in the doubles, came out ahead by the same
score.
As is shown by the fact that two
of the matches went into an extra
set, the competition was quite close
at all times, particularly-in the Challenger-Wells meeting in which the
former won but one more game
than th'e Hopkins representative.
The match was played more or
less under difficulties, there being
but one court available for the contestants.
Scores—Singles:
Horty, Delaware, defeated Duffy,
Hopkins, 6-1, 3-6, 6-4.
Barker, Delaware defeated Rowland Hopkins, 6-2, 6-3.
Pickford, Hopkins, defeated Gutauvitz, Delaware, 6-3, 6-2.
Challenger, Delaware, defeated
Wells, Hopkins, 8-6, 3-6, 6-4.
Doubles:
Horty and Barker, Delaware,
over Duffy and Rowland, Hopkins,
6-1, 612.
Pickford and Wells, Hopkins,
over Gutauvitz and Challenger,
Delaware, 6-3, 6-2.
